"That’s stuck with me because it’s something I do myself. We had great times at Burnley and he was the star of the group. I’ve got a great relationship with him and his dad, who was always very grateful for us looking after him."

Gore has been on an upward trajectory since and Bruno Fernandes is understood to have been very welcoming to the youngster, taking a hands-on role in his integration into the first-team. Sources have also indicated Jonny Evans has been especially supportive and offered Gore plenty of advice since they started training together in mid-July, which the 19-year-old has appreciated.

"You’re around top players every day at United and you either adapt or die," Craig said. "Even if he ends up making 100 appearances for United in the Premier League or with another club, he'll get the most out of himself.
"Ten Hag has been known for developing youngsters at Ajax and he doesn’t put people in who aren’t good enough. I'm really proud of him and it's lovely when you bump into him, or get a text."

Hargreaves echoed those comments: "It’s been brilliant to see him progress and I’m a United fan myself, so I'm extremely pleased because it's more than he deserves. I genuinely think he embodies what a United player should be, bringing excitement, being hard-working and holding himself in the right way."

Gore recently shaved his head - going for a buzzcut style - and there was a large smile on his face when he revealed his new haircut to his amused teammates at Carrington. That wide grin doesn't seem to be going away anytime soon.

headline: Manchester United make decision on Amad's future
body: Amad joined Man United from Atalanta in October 2020 but he has only played 10 times for the club.
Manchester United are planning to keep Amad beyond the closure of the January transfer window.
United expect Facundo Pellistri to join Granada on loan and believe Amad has an important role to play in the squad.
Amad, 21, made his first United appearance in more than two years as a substitute in the 2-1 defeat to Nottingham Forest on January 30.
The Ivory Coast international missed the FA Cup third round win against Wigan Athletic through illness and he could return to the squad for the fourth round tie at Newport County next week.
United signed Amad for £19million rising to £37m from Atalanta on transfer deadline day in October 2020 and the winger has played 10 times for the club.
EXCLUSIVE: Brailsford meeting former United staff with 'brutal' changes planned

Amad spent the second half of the 2021-22 season on loan at Rangers and shone during a season-long loan at Sunderland last term. Amad scored 14 goals in 42 games for the Championship side as Sunderland reached the play-offs.
Pellistri was due to leave on loan in the summer but ended up remaining at United after Amad sustained a knee injury in the pre-season win against Arsenal in July.
Amad returned to training in early December and he performed creditably off the bench in the loss at Forest.

headline: Borussia Dortmund fire clear Jadon Sancho transfer message after Manchester United move
body: Borussia Dortmund's sporting director Sebastian Kehl has explained why it would be hard to strike a deal with Manchester United for Jadon Sancho
Borussia Dortmund sporting director Sebastian Kehl has conceded it's unlikely Jadon Sancho will sign for the club permanently - even if Manchester United look to offload the forward in the summer.

The 23-year-old, who spent four years at Dortmund after signing from Manchester City in 2017, returned to the club last month on a loan deal until the end of the season. His return to the Bundesliga from Old Trafford came after a public falling out with manager Erik ten Hag back in September.

Since returning to the Signal Iduna Park, Sancho has provided two assists in three Bundesliga games and helped Edin Terzic's side kick-start their pursuit of Champions League qualification with three consecutive league wins.
However, Kehl has all-but-ruled out Sancho making his return to Dortmund permanent, insisting that the price United would demand for the forward would make any future deal "very, very difficult."

Speaking to Sky Sports Germany, Kehl said: "Unfortunately for both players [Ian Maatsen and Jadon Sancho], neither option was really realistic. If you know what we got for Jadon Sancho two and a half years ago, then you know also that it might now be very, very difficult.
"We naturally advocated for an option with him - and also with Ian - but the negotiating position was not such that we could implement it and so we will accept it for now."
It remains to be seen if Sancho, whose deal at Old Trafford runs until 2026, will ever play for United under Ten Hag again.

headline: Manchester United give team news update as two players could return vs West Ham
body: Sofyan Amrabat and Victor Lindelof are in line to return to the Manchester United squad against West Ham on Sunday.

Amrabat has not played since the goalless draw with Liverpool on December 17 due to injury and his participation with Morocco at the Africa Cup of Nations. Lindelof has been sidelined since December 6 after undergoing groin surgery.
Long-term absentees Tyrell Malacia (knee) and Mason Mount (calf) are still unavailable and Aaron Wan-Bissaka (leg) is unlikely to return after missing the wins against Wolves and Newport County.

"Sofyan will return to training on Saturday," United manager Erik ten Hag said. "Ty and Mason Mount I don’t expect them back, but I think Victor Lindelof is almost back. Yesterday he trained with the team and we have to see how far he is.
"Aaron Wan-Bissaka is also on his way back. I don’t think he will make it for Sunday but I’m not sure at this moment. There is a problem in his leg. It’s personal, you know that."

Lisandro Martinez made his first Premier League start in nearly five months at Molineux but required ice on his foot following his removal in the 86th minute. Casemiro also made way in the second half on his first league start since October 7 but Ten Hag clarified that was a precaution as he had been yellow-carded in the third minute and conceded a penalty that Pablo Sarabia converted on 71 minutes.

"It was a precaution (to take Martinez off). I had to sub Rasmus Hojlund because he was dead with all his running," Ten Hag explained. "Then we needed an extra header. But also I think for Licha, he was of course a long way out and we brought Harry Maguire on as an extra header and Omari (Forson) for Rasmus.
"Also, [Casemiro] has to catch up as well, Case. I know the more games he plays, the better he will be. But he needs some game minutes, that’s what he takes the most benefit from.
"In that moment, I think with another foul maybe he would have been sent off so we couldn’t take the risk."

headline: Manchester United players' gesture shows how important Kobbie Mainoo already is
body: Kobbie Mainoo is one of the success stories of the Premier League season and he only made his first start in November.
Revisiting one's first assessment of Kobbie Mainoo in an FA Youth Cup semi-final offers reassurance. Dated March 9 2022, the sentence reads: "Kobbie Mainoo, in midfield, was exceptional."

Mainoo's first Premier League goal 694 days later was also exceptional. Even as it dawned on him that he had clipped in a 97th-minute winner and faced with the sight of grown men and women clambering over each other in the tiered moshpit of the Steve Bull Stand, Mainoo celebrated as calmly as he had scored. He spread his arms with the nonchalance of a rock star at the conclusion of an encore.
By the time he had finished his first on-pitch televised interview, almost every Manchester United supporter had vacated their gold-coloured seat. Mainoo is their golden boy.
FROM 2022: Impressing Ten Hag and Ronaldo - Mainoo set for his next breakthrough at United
FROM 2023: Same parking spot and living at home - how Kobbie Mainoo is keeping his feet on the ground at United

The premium pro of Erik ten Hag's tenure is he has bestowed United two academy legacies, turning the boys Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho into men. Garnacho, too, registered a first league goal in added time in front of an away end last season.

Garnacho hoisted his shirt to brandish his name and number to those in the Putney End at Fulham. Mainoo exercised a different variety of audacity: shifting past one Wolves defender, nutmegging another, bypassing a third before arching the ball beyond the goalkeeper's palm.

You'll have replayed it already but have another look. When Mainoo veers inside, Bruno Fernandes is practically demanding he pass the ball. Fernandes, the outfield player farthest away, sprints to join the throng.

Fernandes has been especially welcoming amid Mainoo's integration into the first-team squad. Jonny Evans is another teammate who has offered invaluable advice. Evans, twice the age of Mainoo, grinned as broadly as a proud father when he grabbed Mainoo at Molineux.

United players' appreciation of Mainoo is palpable. Diogo Dalot, Harry Maguire and Luke Shaw all congratulated him on his full Premier League debut at Everton in November and more teammates queued up to compliment Mainoo on his game management at Wolves.

The engaging Rasmus Hojlund stopped in the mixed zone and the first two questions were on Mainoo. Hojlund jumped onto the pitch and into Maguire's arms with the ball rolling around the net. He had Mainoo in a clinch at full-time.
Umpteen column inches have already been dedicated to Mainoo by this newspaper and we hope that will continue well beyond this decade. He is a potential long-term linchpin for United.

Ten Hag named Mainoo on the bench in his 13th match as manager. He took him to the winter training camp in Cadiz during the World Cup, there was a debut last January and Mainoo would have been a first-teamer sooner had he not been collateral damage in Casemiro's foul on the Real Madrid winger Rodrygo in July.

Any aspiring academy graduate intending to walk past Carrington's fountain of youth, with the 249 names who have appeared for the first team glazed onto a glass display, need only look at Mainoo's development. It is the new blueprint.

It was more like the Ten Hag of last season at Wolves and that extended to his post-match press conference. He had "mixed feelings" that United had not won as handsomely as they should have. He revealed his hot-housing of Mainoo started with haste.

"I think very quickly I saw him," Ten Hag recalled. "I think last autumn (of 2022) I saw him for the first time and at that moment I thought he was playing a little bit too comfortable in the under-21s, he should be much more dominant.
"We pushed him a lot by that side, by pushing him in the training and you see he makes such good progress and he is almost progressing from game to game.
"And of course, it's wonderful to see and I hope he stays calm like he is, as he did with his goal as well. He is determined, he is a good character and I hope he keeps going with this progress."

England will inevitably come calling. Beyond the generational talents of Jude Bellingham and Declan Rice, there is a dearth of inspiring out-and-out central midfielders in the national team squad and Mainoo's form is impossible to ignore. Would anyone objectively prefer Conor Gallagher or Jordan Henderson to Mainoo?

United supporters will understandably hope he remains out of Gareth Southgate's clutches until at least after the European Championship. If Southgate was loyal to his maxim that players are picked on form then Mainoo would be a shoo-in for the Euros.

Mainoo has fewer games for United than his 18 years but consider the tests he has passed: the bear pit of Goodison, the lion's den at Galatasaray and United's old graveyard at Anfield. In the one game he memorably erred at West Ham, his performance is still remembered for the accomplished 77 minutes that preceded his miscontrol.

The anguish etched on Mainoo's face that afternoon in London was almost as endearing as his cheerleading at Anfield six days earlier. In an age where footballers appear more detached from matchgoers than ever, Mainoo represents the United fan on the pitch.

Mainoo is so integral his tactical removal during the interval at Nottingham Forest consigned United to defeat. Ten Hag insisted he had "no regrets" about that. Mainoo has started all four games since and has not been hooked in any of them.

So already it is a question of which midfielder starts with Mainoo, rather than does Mainoo start. In the Tombola selection of midfield pairings, last week at Newport was the first time Ten Hag was able to select Mainoo and Casemiro since pre-season.

It is not a coincidence Mainoo has gone from guard to goal-getter with Casemiro the sentry. United will require a central midfielder in the summer and should tailor their recruitment in that area around Mainoo's skill set.
For he is exceptional.

headline: Manchester United could be without four players vs West Ham United
body: Man United could be without four players for Sunday's Premier League encounter against West Ham United
Manchester United could be without as many as four players for Sunday's Premier League clash against West Ham United at Old Trafford.

Erik Ten Hag's side, fresh from their dramatic 4-3 win at Molineux on Thursday, know victory against the Hammers could move them to within four points of fourth-place Tottenham Hotspur. However, it could prove to be a challenging afternoon for Ten Hag, who is set to be without a series of regular United first-teamers as the club's injury problems continue to mount.
As expected, Anthony Martial will play no part in United's next Premier League match as he continues to recover from surgery he had on a groin issue last month.

At this stage, no timeline has been placed on when the Frenchman could return to action at Old Trafford and - with his contract expiring in the summer - it is therefore unsure if he will ever appear for the Reds again.

Providing an update on his condition last month, Ten Hag said: "Anthony has completed successful surgery to address a groin complaint and will be out of action for about ten weeks as he rehabilitates."
Meanwhile, Mason Mount and Tyrell Malacia - plagued with injuries this term - have both made sizeable steps in their road to recovery in recent weeks by training on the grass at Carrington.

However, given the extensive lay-offs both players have endured, they are likely to be phased back into action under Ten Hag, with neither expected to feature against West Ham this weekend. Aaron Wan Bissaka is also expected to miss out.
Lisandro Martinez was seen having his foot strapped up after being substituted against Wolves, but Erik ten Hag said afterwards that it was a precautionary measure.
Though there could be a fitness boost for United this weekend with Sofyan Amrabat and Victor Lindelof in line for returns at Old Trafford.

United loanee Amrabat has not featured since December's stalemate at Anfield due to injury and Africa Cup of Nations participation with Morocco but Ten Hag confirmed the midfielder will take part in training on Saturday and could be involved.
As well as Amrabat, United could also welcome back Lindelof, who has been sidelined since December after undergoing groin surgery.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo's Cristiano Ronaldo stat proves Erik ten Hag is keeping his Manchester United promise
body: Man United have a new young star after Kobbie Mainoo dragged the Reds to a crucial victory at Wolverhampton Wanderers on Thursday
Many clubs speak about their 'DNA' and a lot of the time it is laughable.

For most teams, whichever style of football gets results should be the DNA. Whether this be investing heavily to bring in the best stars or developing them through the academy, a club should choose whichever route is most viable to them.

However, at Manchester United, an expectation has emerged regarding the importance of giving youth a chance. Throughout history, some of the Reds' best squads have had a youthful core propelling them to glory.

Erik ten Hag alluded to this in December when asked about the likes of Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo being given opportunities. "I think it’s in the DNA of Manchester United; the Busby Babes, the Class of '92," he insisted.

"Developing players into the first team should be one key area of Manchester United because this club is very successful with it and we are now bringing up players. It is a big advantage that young players always have a very good connection with the fans and it gives a club identity."

This assurance of a pathway from the reserves to the first team is often easier said than done but one key statistic proves the Reds' boss is keeping to his promise. Mainoo's stunning winner on Thursday night at Molineux is only the second time in Premier League history a goal has been scored and assisted by teenagers - Omari Forson was credited with setting up the midfielder in the West Midlands.

The only previous example of this came at Anfield as a young Cristiano Ronaldo provided Wayne Rooney with a goal in 2005. Ten Hag may have had his fair share of deserved criticism this season with results being below par.

But, should the new regime decide to fire the Dutchman at the end of the season, he shall at least leave behind a legacy of reintegrating the academy back into the club. While results may be bleak and the table not making for good reading, the emergence of Garnacho, Mainoo and now Forson shows there is light at the end of the tunnel for the Reds. It's in the club's DNA, after all.

headline: Erik ten Hag could be about to find out how many summer signings he needs at Manchester United
body: The summer of 2024 will be a critical one in taking Man United to the next stage of their development.
When it comes to the task of selecting his starting line-up for Sunday's clash with West Ham United, Erik ten Hag ought not to encounter too many difficulties.

Thursday night's 4-3 win over Wolves felt as though it could prove to be a significant juncture in Manchester United's season. After throwing away a lead in stoppage time, Kobbie Mainoo spared United's blushes with a moment of individual brilliance.

In an arena that features golden seats, United's golden boy injected fresh energy into their season, finding the back of the net with a goal that will be spoken about for years to come. Though the 4-3 scoreline suggested United had edged an even contest, it was anything but.

United, particularly in the first half, produced their most polished performance of the season. Some may go as far as saying the football on show in the first 45 minutes was the best they have produced under Ten Hag.

Though it featured a familiar flaw in the form of missed chances, United's first-half showing in the Black Country, which saw them head into the half-time interval with a two-goal lead, was superb. Featuring a clear identity, energy and hunger, United, with more composure, would have been home and dry.

Lisandro Martinez added organisation and his ball-playing credentials to the back-four. Luke Shaw added an extra attacking threat from left-back. Marcus Rashford, recalled after a disciplinary issue, caused havoc down the left. Rasmus Hojlund led the line with maturity. Mainoo, as ever, oozed class in midfield.

Everything that could have gone right in the first half did go right. Defensive flaws crept in after the break, particularly in the manner in which United conceded for a third time, but everything else was on point.

Ten Hag had quipped for several weeks that he expected United to get back to their best once their injury crisis had eased and the likes of Martinez, Shaw and Casemiro returned. He was within his rights to stand by that argument based on Thursday night's evidence.

Of course, the challenge for United now is to prove that Thursday night's showing was not a flash in the pan. False dawns have been a far too familiar theme this season. They must prove that the performance they produced at Molineux can be replicated week after week.

For many, United now have the ingredients available to them to find some much-needed consistency, following the returns of the likes of Martinez and Shaw, who are both critical to the way Ten Hag wants his team to play. With those two available, the Dutchman now has a crop of players available to him that help form the strongest XI currently at the club.

The XI Ten Hag deployed at Molineux is United's strongest currently. It featured a goalkeeper of Ten Hag's choice, a ball-playing centre-back, a midfielder with enormous potential, one of the most accomplished attacking midfielders in the world, an exciting winger and a £72million striker.

This forthcoming summer will mark the next stage of Ten Hag's gradual rebuild, meaning further additions are expected. With INEOS overseeing recruitment, it is hoped that United will be wise in their thinking and not repeat any mistakes of yesteryear.

It is understood that United have provisionally drawn up a list of four positions they wish to strengthen next season: right-back, centre-back, central-midfield and up front. Of the XI that started at Molineux, you can argue upgrades, for the long-term, are needed at right-back, centre-back and in defensive-midfield.

Diogo Dalot has frequently contested the right-back spot with Aaron Wan-Bissaka over the past 12 months, with Ten Hag failing to settle on a first-choice option. Raphael Varane's fitness is unreliable, meaning United need to source a long-term partner for Martinez. Casemiro turns 32 later this month and is, it is felt, past his peak.

Should Ten Hag receive strong financial backing from Sir Jim Ratcliffe, finding a new right-back, a centre-back and a replacement for Casemiro should be United's three main objectives this summer. They must also find someone to provide competition and back-up for Hojlund.

Those three starting positions aside, United have a cluster of players capable of taking the club forward. The left-wing may come under scrutiny, too, but it shouldn't if Rashford performs at his best consistently.

United will, of course, need to add strength in depth this summer, certainly within reason, but three statement signings to go into the first XI could be enough. It is now down to United's existing players to prove it.

headline: Manchester United's Isak Hansen-Aarøen transfer highlights ruthless Erik ten Hag approach
body: Man United youngster Isak Hansen-Aarøen completed a permanent transfer to German side Werder Bremen on deadline day.
Erik ten Hag singled out Hannibal Mejbri for praise during a press conference in September and, just a few months later, the youngster signed for Sevilla.

Hannibal enjoyed a mini-breakthrough in the first-team but was unable to nail down a regular starting place in the following weeks and that led to his departure. Sevilla have signed Hannibal on a loan for the remainder of the season with the option to make the deal permanent, which means he could have played his last game for United.

Hannibal's departure after breaking into the first-team and being lavished with praise by his manager shows how difficult it is for youngsters to bridge the gap to the senior squad. The demands are high - particularly each day in training - and only the best prospects from the academy are kept around the squad, like Alejandro Garnacho and Thursday night's hero Kobbie Mainoo.

Other players are sent on loan to accelerate their development, but this window has also seen the departure of several youngsters on permanent deals. Mateo Mejia joined Sevilla earlier in the window and Isak Hansen-Aarøen signed for Werder Bremen on transfer deadline day. The latter was well-regarded by coaches and many supporters were hoping he would extend his stay at Old Trafford.

Hansen-Aarøen, 19, was out of contract in the summer and sources indicated he was offered a 'significant' new deal. But it's understood the player was frustrated over his lack of opportunities and felt a permanent move away was the best option for his career. He was overlooked in FA Cup matches against Wigan Athletic and Newport County when his peers were given minutes, which contributed to his decision to leave.
There were high hopes for Hansen-Aarøen when he arrived in Manchester from Tromsø in August 2020. He was considered one of Norway's most exciting talents.

Those familiar with Norwegian football suggested that Hansen-Aarøen was a better prospect than Manchester City's Oscar Bobb when he initially made the switch to England, but one player's progress stalled at Old Trafford while the other's has blossomed at the Etihad. It was inevitable that Hansen-Aarøen would look at his friend Bobb's progress and question his situation at United, wondering why Ten Hag wasn't giving him opportunities.

Hansen-Aarøen has left the club without making a debut and there's a feeling of what could have been, so it will be fascinating to see how he develops in the Bundesliga. There is emerging and senior talent in his position at United and Werder Bremen should give him the opportunities he's been desperate for after multiple seasons of academy football.

Regarding the deal itself, sources have indicated the sale has secured United a better package than the expected compensation fee that would have been received if Hansen-Aarøen left when his contract expired. Werder Bremen have paid a fee and the terms inserted in the deal by United have been described as favourable.

It's understood the deal includes add-ons, a high percentage sell-on clause and future matching rights for prospective buyers down the line. Hansen-Aarøen wanted to leave this month and United believe they have negotiated a good deal in the circumstances.

headline: I saw what Manchester United did in the January transfer window and it made perfect sense
body: Man United transfer news as the January window closes with Erik ten Hag and the club opting not to add to the squad
Manchester United were caught between a rock and a hard place last month.

They could try and creatively add to their squad with loans or sit tight and save their money and moves for the summer. In the end they chose the latter, partly influenced by the summer spending spree that Erik ten Hag has been on over the past two seasons and partly by the nature of the winter window.

It’s often a time for panic buys and poor decisions. United have made enough of those in recent years without seeking to add to them this month. Even last year’s seemingly no-lose scenario of bringing in Wout Weghorst on loan ended in ridicule with the striker failing to find the net in the Premier League. United thought better of it before seeking a loan repeat this time around despite the clear need for reinforcements.

Ineos will hope to improve and shape the squad in the summer with something of an overhaul needed. Sir Jim Ratcliffe is awaiting Premier League ratification after the investment was approved on Christmas Eve and attention will already be on what comes next.

January had long been expected to be quiet and the Reds were not alone in keeping their powder dry with many of their Premier League rivals adopting a similar approach. Yet United’s need is greater than most.

They have squad holes to fill and several important decisions to be made. The prospect of missing out on Champions League football won’t help their pulling power and the summer is once again looking like a crucial one.

Ineos and Ten Hag, assuming he remains in post, will need to hit the ground running as a pair and ensure their transfer success rate is a high one. Ratcliffe wants to restore the Reds to the top table and as things stand they’re ill-equipped to do so. It will be a major test of both parties as they seek to thrust United back into contention for sustained trophy challenges.
January was the calm before what could be a storm of summer activity.

headline: 'It’s a mess' - Manchester United transfers slammed by Premier League title winner
body: Latest Manchester United transfer news and gossip as four-time Premier League title winner Anderson has criticised the club's recent transfer business and the effect it's had on the pitch
Former Manchester United star Anderson has slammed his old club's business in the transfer market in recent years.

Anderson made 181 appearances for United from 2007-15, scoring nine goals from midfield. The 35-year-old was signed by Sir Alex Ferguson from Porto and went on to win four Premier League titles while at Old Trafford.
It has been nearly a decade since Anderson left the club to return to Brazil. Now the former midfielder, who retired in 2019, has weighed in on United's current situation under manager Erik ten Hag.

Anderson has criticised United's business in the transfer market, in particular overspending on certain deals. While not naming any players specifically, Anderson has explained why he thinks his former club could have been more shrewd in the market with some of the signings that have been made.

“Nowadays, small clubs go to play at Old Trafford, and are not afraid," Anderson said in an interview with Globo Esporte. "Today, the club doesn’t know which manager it will have, who controls it. It’s a mess. Manchester United sometimes buy very badly. If you’re going to pay €100 million (£85 million) for a player, pay for Neymar.
“A player who will make a difference. Manchester United pay €70m, €80m , €90m for players who have no logic. I think the club’s desperation is so great that anyone will do.”

United have signed 10 players on permanent deals since Ten Hag was appointed back in 2022. More than £400 million has been spent across the last two summer transfer windows alone, with Mason Mount, Lisandro Martinez, Casemiro, Antony, Christian Eriksen, Tyrell Malacia, Andre Onana, Ramsus Hojlund, Altay Bayindir and Jonny Evans all arriving on a permanent basis since Ten Hag was hired.

After finishing third in the Premier League and winning the Carabao Cup last season, this campaign has been more of a struggle for United and Ten Hag. The club went into their away game at Wolves in ninth place in the table and 11 points adrift of the top four spots with a game in hand.

headline: How Manchester United can still sell unwanted players after January transfer window closed
body: Donny van de Beek, Hannibal Mejbri and Jadon Sancho were among 11 departures in the January transfer window and Man United could still yet sell more players.

The clock struck 11pm on Thursday night with not so much as a bang but a whimper. Manchester United and their Premier League rivals were particularly quiet during the January transfer window for 2024.

Owing to lingering FFP caution - coupled with a significant £180million spend last summer - United were always expected to focus on outgoings last month. That proved to be the case into the final knockings despite finalised investment from Sir Jim Ratcliffe as INEOS Group continue to await Premier League ratification.

As things played out, there was not enough wiggle room in the budget for United to add to their options in the push for a top-four finish. However, true to plan, they were able to rubber-stamp quite a few departures such as Donny van de Beek, Hannibal Mejbri and the ousted Jadon Sancho.
Those three - and others - departed Old Trafford on loan. A permanent exit was also sealed with Bundesliga side Werder Bremen paying an undisclosed fee to snap up Isak Hansen-Aaroen.
The highly-rated youngster was allowed to leave owing to concerns over his long-term future. The playmaker was into the final six months of his contract with no sign of an extension being agreed.

By the time the window slammed shut on Thursday night, United had sanctioned 12 departures and they could in theory add to their exodus before next summer rolls around. That's because there are still one or two markets still open for business despite the widespread European cut-off on February 1.

Clubs in Portugal have until Friday night (February 2) to conclude their business, while there is a little while longer still to go in Austria (February 6) and Turkey (February 9). The latter is a particularly interesting option for United as they sold Brazil international Fred to Fenerbahce for £12.9million last summer.

Aside from van de Beek and Sancho - who moved away on loan - United were open to selling three other senior players during the January window. However, the club also emphasised that they did not intend to force Raphael Varane, Casemiro or Anthony Martial out.
Varane and Casemiro have returned to the starting XI in recent weeks. Martial, meanwhile, is struggling with a hip injury and is expected to depart United next summer.

headline: Manchester United's next six Premier League fixtures compared with Chelsea, Newcastle and rivals
body: Man United recorded their first Premier League win of 2024 on Thursday night, beating Wolves 4-3 at Molineux.
Manchester United cut the gap on the Premier League's top four to eight points with a dramatic 4-3 win over Wolves at Molineux on Thursday night.

Kobbie Mainoo netted a 97th-minute winner after Pedro Neto had seemingly earned a point for the home side, who had fought back from 3-1 down. United led 2-0 at half-time after goals from Marcus Rashford and Rasmus Hojlund.

Pablo Sarabia netted a controversial penalty with just under 20 minutes remaining to halve the deficit but United restored their two-goal advantage through Scott McTominay. Max Kilman then struck before Neto drew the home side level.

Mainoo then produced a moment of magic to secure a vital three points for the Reds and lift them up to seventh in the table. With the race for European football for next season now looking even tighter, MEN Sport has had a look at United's next six league fixtures and compared them with those of their immediate rivals.

Verdict: United's upcoming crop of fixtures feature a mixed bag of assignments. The trip to the Etihad Stadium for the Manchester derby on March 3 is by far the most daunting, but the clashes with the likes of Fulham and Everton at home resemble good opportunities for points.

The trips to Aston Villa and Luton Town will be difficult tests for different reasons, and West Ham cannot be underestimated at Old Trafford this coming weekend. But if United are to bridge the gap to the top four, they need to be taking somewhere in the region of 12 to 15 points from the next 18 on offer.

headline: Manchester United are hoping their 'smarter' transfer strategy finally pays off
body: Man Utd focused on player exits in the January transfer window rather than signing new players
Manchester United insist they have the privilege of developing young players as opposed to the pressure of doing so. There is no other club scrutinised at the academy level quite like them.
That is a by-product of the success it has brought them, coupled with the fact that they are very happy to draw attention to it themselves.

Last month, they held their annual academy event at Old Trafford to celebrate their illustrious academy in a year when it is likely they will reach the milestone of having seen 250 homegrown players make their competitive debut. Head of the Academy, Nick Cox, said he was genuinely intrigued by who that might be. Well, it won't be Isak Hansen-Aarøen anyway.

The Norwegian youngster became the latest player to leave the club on loan or a permanent deal in the January transfer window when he sealed a permanent transfer to Werder Bremen. It was a sale that left many supporters disappointed, though from the club's point of view, it made sense rather than risk losing him for free in the summer instead.

The Manchester Evening News revealed earlier this week that United still wanted the teenager to sign a new long-term deal at the club but were open to a sale when it became abundantly clear he would not be signing it.

Hansen-Aarøen felt undervalued by the club and didn't see a clear pathway for him into the first team. He wanted to be playing regularly and to progress with his professional career, though some at the club believe he was unrealistic about what he expected at such a young age.

The harsh truth is that while he wielded dreams of making it at United and they still felt he had huge potential, he wasn't in a position to fulfil it just yet. It's another example of a transfer policy change since Erik ten Hag arrived.

Ten Hag has taken on a more hands-on approach with the academy since he joined the club, having felt the U21s were 'isolated' before his arrival. He now takes an active role in deciding which youngsters train with the first team and has set the challenge for at least one youth team player to become part of the first team during every season he's at the club.
A key reason why he was appointed was because of his track record of nurturing youth talent and he has helped to raise those standards during his time at the club.
Ten Hag won't give youngsters an opportunity just to keep up traditions and he has made it clear that only the very best youth prospects will be given a chance in the senior set-up.
Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo have been given those chances, while others have been moved on given the slim likelihood of them ever making it at the club.

As well as the sale of Hansen-Aarøen, Hannibal Mejbri moved to Sevilla on an initial loan with the option of a permanent sale and Alvaro Fernandez left in a similar deal to join Benfica. In total, United loaned out nine players in the window just gone, while Anthony Elanga, Zidane Iqbal, Matej Kovar, Teden Mengi, Axel Tuanzebe, Ethan Laird, Charlie Savage, Noam Emeran, and Marc Jurado were all allowed to leave last summer.

United have aimed to become "smarter" in terms of selling academy graduates and they have also become a lot more ruthless, with staff suspecting players are going "stale and sour" if they stay at the club too long without getting an opportunity to play. That was proven this week.

Then there is the financial side of it all. "Every football club has an academy to try to produce young players to go and play for the first team," Cox told The Manchester Evening News. "That's originally why Manchester United had an academy, because it was the best way of creating a team from an economic point of view."

Now it is economic to view the academy as a money-making machine as well. The current Financial Fair Play rules mean it is hugely beneficial to a club to sell homegrown players because the profit on the sale is purely classified as income.

So while there might be dismay at the number of youngsters currently leaving the club, it could well be a masterstroke that frees up finances elsewhere and lands them a sizeable windfall from a sell-on clause in the years to come.
The youngsters leaving United do so with a point to prove. It would benefit United if they proved it as well.

It's the January transfer window once again, but despite United's indifferent start to the season, it remains to be seen whether they'll be able to bring any new players to Old Trafford this month. While the emphasis this January is on outgoings, with several players set to be sold or loaned out, there remains a possibility of a loan signing or two before February arrives.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo becoming what Manchester United's players knew he would be
body: Man United won 4-3 against Wolves in the Premier League on Thursday after a late matchwinner from Kobbie Mainoo.
Rasmus Hojlund has revealed Manchester United's players described Kobbie Mainoo as a 'generational talent' when they returned from the pre-season tour of the United States.

United delivered their best first-half performance of the season at Molineux and they had a two-goal lead by the interval thanks to goals from Marcus Rashford and Hojlund. But, despite creating plenty of chances, a third proved elusive and Wolves halved the deficit with 20 minutes remaining.

Casemiro brought down Neto in the box and VAR stuck with the referee's decision. Wolves converted from the spot and Ten Hag introduced Scott McTominay to the game. McTominay made an immediate impact when scoring from a corner and the result looked to be wrapped up, but Wolves mounted a dramatic comeback and made it 3-3 in added time.

The points looked set to be shared until United responded at the other end through Mainoo, who did brilliantly to find the bottom right corner. Mainoo, who was the breakout star of the pre-season tour of the USA, has been exceptional this season and Hojlund lauded him when speaking to TNT Sport after the final whistle.

"I know I'm not allowed to swear, but I was thinking 's***, s****' [when Wolves equalised] but it's a great goal. We need to sort them situations out and I was fuming on the bench of course," Hojlund said.

"We need to do better and everybody knows that, but we managed to turn it around again. I didn't really get to see him [Mainoo] in pre-season because I wasn't there, but all the other lads were speaking about him and saying he was an incredible talent, a generational talent.
"He has a nice body type, he's very mature already in his personality as well. He's very calm and outside the pitch, he's just and calm and nice guy. He's very composed and he knows his quality,
"He showed it again today. He's an incredible talent, he's only 18 years old. I thought I was young, he's just stepping up at the age of 18."

Hojlund assisted Rashford for the first goal and he also discussed the blossoming connection with his teammates: "It's about time. You need to get connections inside the team and I'm always telling them that if they play the pass and I'm not there, they can scream at me and destroy me outside the pitch.

"But the opposite way, if they don't play the pass and I'm there, I can scream at them. I think it's a good chemistry we're starting to get and I think everyone can see the relationship we have now, me, Rashford and Garna."

headline: Manchester United 'turned down' January striker deal as '€100m' goalkeeper linked
body: Man United transfer news with the latest rumours following the closure of the January window
Kobbie Mainoo scored a 97th-minute winner as United beat Wolverhampton Wanderers 4-3 at Molineux in a Premier League classic on Thursday night.

The young midfielder curled his first Premier League goal past Jose Sa, just seconds after Pedro Neto appeared to have rescued a point for the hosts. United had led 2-0 and 3-1 before being pegged back in stoppage time.
Manchester United finished the January transfer window without a new signing being added to Erik ten Hag's squad.

However, if reports are to be believed, they could have added a new striker on deadline day in the shape of Borussia Dortmund's Sebastien Haller. According to HITC, United were one of three Premier League clubs offered the chance to sign the former West Ham forward late in the window.

The report also claims that Chelsea and Newcastle United were approached by the striker's entourage. Wolves had been linked with Haller on deadline day, as were Fulham, who eventually signed Armando Broja from the Stamford Bridge club on loan.
Ten Hag worked with Haller during his time at Ajax, where he scored 47 times in 66 appearances, leading the United boss to describe the Ivory Coast international as 'phenomenal'.
Benfica goalkeeper Anatoliy Trubin has been mentioned as a potential Manchester United summer signing by his agent.

The Reds replaced David de Gea with Andre Onana in the summer, but a handful of errors have resulted in many calling for a change once again. And it appears Trubin could be an option, as in an interview with Povoroznyuk Dmytro, via Sport Witness, the player's representative, Maryna Andriienko, was quizzed about the long-term future of the Ukraine international.
He said: “Let’s wait for the summer, Trubin could get there with even more visibility. Manchester United? I’m not going to talk about it, it’ll be a secret, let’s keep it a mystery."
Trubin only joined Benfica last summer from Shakhtar Donetsk and it is claimed has a €100million release clause in his contract.

headline: Manchester United's unsung hero became irreplaceable again in moment vs Wolves
body: Man Utd scored late on to secure all three points against Wolves at Molineux on Thursday night.

It is only right that Kobbie Mainoo is hailed as the hero after his sensational stoppage-time winner at Molineux on Thursday night. After all, he produced the decisive moment to end a dramatic match in which Manchester United were almost as bad as they were good.

He wasn't the only United player who made a huge difference. Mainoo might be the one who adorns the back pages, but further inside, there deserves to be a special mention for Luke Shaw, a player who lifted United again.
The 28-year-old caught the eye with his industrious performance against Newport at the weekend, but the real test was always going to be his first Premier League since before Christmas.
Shaw has been short of match sharpness since that latest injury lay-off, yet he still lasted the entire 100 minutes at Molineux, offering a constant threat down the left wing.

His partnership with Marcus Rashford is one of the most unsung in the Premier League and whenever anyone mentions the forward's remarkable 30-goal haul last season, it is important to note his support in making it happen.

It is obvious Rashford has seen a clear drop-off in this season compared with last, but it is important to note Shaw's absences as a key factor in that. Shaw only missed eight matches across their mammoth 62-match campaign last season. He has missed 20 games so far this season.

A key part of Rashford's game is running at isolated full-backs and exploiting the space in the channels so that he can cut inside onto his dominant foot. It can be infuriating at times and at others, it can be inspirational. However, for it to work, he needs the support of a left-back who can both underlap and overlap, draw defenders out of position and be available to exchange passes.

This was no more apparent than with United's second goal of the night, when Rashford controlled the ball on the edge of the Wolves box and within seconds Shaw ran behind him to create an overload on the left wing.

Shaw timed his run to perfection, reading the game so well that he was able to play a first-time cross into the near post straight into the path of Rasmus Hojlund, rather than taking a touch that would have killed momentum and meant the striker had to make another run inside the box.
The left-back won't get much credit for the assist because it looked so simple. That in itself is the biggest compliment you can pay to a player who doesn't overcomplicate things.

It is true that his positioning wasn't great when Wolves finally drew things level deep in injury time, though he wasn't the only United player exposed when Antony inexcusably lost the ball at the other end of the pitch.

Further improvement will be required from both individuals and United as a collective in the weeks ahead, with Shaw one of those who should get even better once he has a run of games under his belt. If all goes well, he will soon be one of the first names on the teamsheet again, a player who is almost taken for granted due to his reliability and monopoly on a starting role.
Mainoo deserves to dominate the headlines. Shaw deserves to be recognised for his supporting role.

headline: Jude Bellingham allegedly reported to La Liga over Manchester United loanee Mason Greenwood 'slur'
body: Real Madrid midfielder Jude Bellingham faced Manchester United loanee Mason Greenwood's Getafe in La Liga on Thursday evening
Spanish media are claiming that Getafe have reported Jude Bellingham to La Liga officials after the England midfielder allegedly called Manchester United loanee Mason Greenwood a ‘rapist’.

The incident occurred during Getafe's 2-0 defeat to Real Madrid on Thursday evening. After the ball went out of play, the television camera caught Bellingham saying a two-syllable word towards Greenwood, although the audio did not pick up exactly what the England midfielder said.

After the final whistle, Cadena SER reports that Getafe requested to the La Liga delegate at the game that Bellingham’s alleged slur is included in the official match report, which could then open an investigation into the incident. Bellingham, if charged and found guilty by La Liga, could be handed a potential suspension as a result, although it remains unclear if officials will take action.

Greenwood was suspended by United in January 2022 amid allegations of attempted rape, assault and controlling and coercive behaviour. A lengthy investigation into the case then followed, with the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) dropping all charges against Greenwood in February 2023.

A United statement at the time read: "Manchester United notes the decision of the Crown Prosecution Service that all charges against Mason Greenwood have been dropped. The club will now conduct its own process before determining next steps. We will not make any further comment until that process is complete."
Greenwood left United for Getafe on loan following the conclusion of that internal investigation last year. The 22-year-old's contract at Old Trafford expires in the summer of 2025.

headline: Manchester United give fresh update on Mason Mount
body: Mason Mount had injury issues last season before Man United agreed to sign him from Chelsea for £60m.
Erik ten Hag admits Manchester United midfielder Mason Mount has been "struggling" with injury issues since August.
Mout joined United from Chelsea for £60million in the summer but he has been sidelined since November 11 with a calf problem and last started a Premier League game on October 7.

The 25-year-old sustained a hamstring injury in the second game of the season at Tottenham and missed the next four matches. Mount suffered a calf injury in training in November but resumed outdoor training in late December and Ten Hag hoped to have him back in January.

However, Mount has resorted to indoor training and could miss the majority of United's fixtures in February. The England international did not start in any of Chelsea's last 18 matches of the 2022-23 campaign due to a pubis injury and he has started nine games in the last year, completing 90 minutes only once.
"He was struggling from the second game of the season," Ten Hag said. "He returned for a period and then picked up another injury, so of course that’s not great.
"That is very frustrating for him and I really feel for him. I really want to be there for him because he had such high expectations and I had high expectations.

"I am sure he is a very good player for us. But, first of all, what’s now important is we have to do it very secure to get him fit. Secure in the process, step by step, don’t force it and then hopefully by the end of the season he can stay fit and fight his way into the team, or at least play a role in his team.
"Absolutely, I expect him to return (before the end of the season)."

headline: Avram Glazer hands out Manchester United gift in public appearance after Sir Jim Ratcliffe investment
body: The official announcement of Sir Jim Ratcliffe's acquisition of a minority stake at Man United came on Christmas Eve.
Avram Glazer gifted a Manchester United shirt to leading cricketer Shaheen Afridi and offered him a visit to Old Trafford after attending a cricket game in Dubai.
The Glazer family recently sold 25 per cent of shares at Old Trafford to billionaire Sir Jim Ratcliffe, who has gained control of football operations as part of the deal.

Ratcliffe's bid of around £1.25billion was made official before Christmas and Joel and Avram Glazer released a joint statement in which they said they were 'delighted' with the deal. The Americans also reiterated their commitment to 'delivering success' at the club.
However, many feel Ratcliffe's acquisition of a minority stake at United signals the beginning of the end for the Glazers in Manchester, following their disastrous 18 years as majority shareholders.

Their long-term future at the club remains uncertain, but Avram Glazer proudly handed over a United shirt as a gift when catching up with cricketer Shaheen Afridi on Thursday night. Afridi is the current captain of the Pakistan national cricket team in the T20I format and he also plays for the Desert Vipers, who are owned by the Glazer family.
Avram Glazer spoke to Afridi after the Vipers' most recent match and when discussing sport, he said: "You need to be good, you need to be healthy and you need to be lucky."

He preceded to hand Afridi a gift and added: "It was a good game and I'm also going to give you this, it's a jersey for Manchester United. If you ever want to come to Old Trafford for a match there, we would love to have you there. Or an American football game, if you watch that, so should we get a picture."

The Glazers added the Desert Vipers to their sporting portfolio in December 2021, which means they now own a cricket franchise, United and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. The Desert Vipers are based in the United Arab Emirates and Avram Glazer said after that takeover of the cricket team: “I am very excited to be a part of UAE T20 at its formation.
"UAE T20 promises to be a world-class event that will be transformative to the growth of cricket in the Emirates.”
The footage of Avram Glazer talking to Afridi represents his first words in public since making a statement after Ratcliffe's investment into United.

headline: 'We didn't know' - Kobbie Mainoo impressing Bruno Fernandes at Manchester United
body: Kobbie Mainoo scored a dramatic winner to help Man United beat Wolves 4-3 at Molineux in the Premier League on Thursday night.
Manchester United captain Bruno Fernandes admitted that Kobbie Mainoo is better than he first anticipated after he scored a dramatic winner in Thursday night's 4-3 win over Wolves at Molineux.

After Pedro Neto appeared to have denied United all three points with a 95th minute equaliser, Mainoo produced a moment of magic two minutes late, plundering his first Premier League goal. He bent home a low shot from just inside the penalty area to seal what was a fully-deserved victory for the Reds.

United had led 2-0 at half-time thanks Marcus Rashford and Rasmus Hojlund and had restored their two-goal advantage through Scott McTominay, who made it 3-1 a few minutes after Wolves had pulled a goal back via a controversial penalty.

The Reds were the better side and fully deserved all three points. But had it not been for Mainoo's late heroics, they would have left the Black Country ruing a whole host of missed opportunities after Wolves came twice came from two goals down to level at 3-3 late on. And Fernandes confessed he did not expect the 18-year-old to be quite so talented.

On netting his first Premier League goal, Mainoo said: "It's a dream come true. Wolves is a tough place to come, they are on a good home run here, so we had to get the win. I haven't come down from it, I still feel like I'm dreaming to be honest. You [interviewer] are going to have to give me a second to come back to it."

headline: Bruno Fernandes sends clear Marcus Rashford message after Manchester United beat Wolves
body: Latest Manchester United news as Erik ten Hag's side face a busy fixture list in the Premier League after claiming a dramatic 4-3 victory over Wolves with Kobbie Mainoo scoring the winner
Manchester United returned to winning ways in the Premier League in dramatic fashion on Thursday night.

United claimed a 4-3 victory over Wolves at Molineux to end a run of back-to-back matches without a win in the top flight, with their previous league victory coming on Boxing Day against Aston Villa. Erik ten Hag's side moved up to seventh in the league table thanks to a Kobbie Mainoo goal in the seventh minute of stoppage time.

Marcus Rashford and Rasmus Hojlund had given United a 2-0 lead at half-time at Molineux. Pablo Sarabia then got a goal from the penalty spot for Wolves, before Scott McTominay put United 3-1 in front minutes after being introduced in the game from the bench.

Wolves struck two late goals from Max Kilman and Pedro Neto, with the latter coming in the fifth of nine added-on minutes in the second half. Just two minutes later though, Mainoo stepped up to win the game for United to spark jubilant scenes in the away end at Molineux.

Rashford was returning to the team after being left out of the squad for Sunday's Newport County game after what ten Hag called an 'internal matter' toward the end of last week. Rashford reported ill for training on Friday having been out in Belfast. United captain Fernandes was quizzed about Rashford's goalscoring return and the noise surrounding the England ace's situation.

"We all have a point to prove every time we come out on the pitch, not only Rashford but everyone else," Fernandes said. "The guys have to step up up front to score goals, they have been brought to the club, that is why Marcus has come through the academy and is in the first team.

"He is a special talent and he’s been proving himself. This season has not been amazing for everyone, not only for Marcus. We know we are not in the position that we want to be, but we have to build up and get into the positions we want to be in at the end of the season."

headline: Bruno Fernandes identifies what Manchester United must improve
body: Man United returned to Premier League action with a 4-3 win over Wolves at Molineux Stadium on Thursday night.
Bruno Fernandes thinks Manchester United must control games better and limit their opponent's opportunities on the counter-attack to enjoy a strong end to the season.

United have endured a difficult campaign and crashed out of European competition before Christmas, while they also exited the Carabao Cup in the early rounds. The FA Cup is the only viable option for silverware and a top four finish in the Premier League is considered unlikely, despite a 4-3 win against Wolves on Thursday night.

Wolves had the chance to jump above United in the table with a win at Molineux but the travelling Reds claimed the three points after a dramatic ending to the match. The win lifted United into seventh, eight points adrift of Tottenham in fourth.

Fernandes spoke to MUTV after the Wolves win and said: "Not delighted with it [performance], but with the result, yes. We wanted to have much more control in the game and obviously not concede goals because one of aims is keeping clean sheets.
"We said that before the game and said it at half-time too. When they got the goal from the corner, they got more confidence, some more counter-attacks and we know how dangerous they are.
"But we created a lot of chances and the overall performance was very good. A little bit chaotic in the last 20 minutes, but Wolves provoked that because of their quality and players.
"At the end, we got the result with an amazing goal from Kobbie. I think it was better for them today playing a tennis match than for us and that's going to be the case on Sunday [against West Ham].

"We have to be careful on the details we have to avoid, to make sure we don't have the same second half as today. The first half was amazing, we could control the game and occupy the half spaces. It's going to be really important on Sunday to do it again because they can counter-attack and we must be really focussed on that."
